Film Reviews

Review: Rogue One

A step forward rather than a regurgitation, Star Wars fans can rejoice with this serious and fresh take on the mythos.

Review: Paterson

Paterson is a film dedicated to finding poetry and beauty in the everyday, says Andrew Young

Review: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them

A film with only mediocre magic, Fantastic Beasts is a lacking fantasy.

Review: The Handmaiden

Park Chan-wook's latest piece may well overtake Oldboy for the title of his best film yet

Review: It's Only the End of the World

Andrew Young offers a rave review for one of 2016's most divisive pieces of cinema

Review: The Light Between Oceans

The Light Between Oceans doesn't pack the same punch as other pieces of sentimental cinema, says Beth Wiffen

Review: Doctor Strange

Doctor Strange is a fun superhero romp elevated by fantastic visuals, creative action set pieces, and a great cast, says Emily Taylor

Aesthetica Short Film Festival 2016: Day 3

Izzy Moore takes on the third day of the film festival, having a look at what University of York TFTV students have to offer

Review: American Honey

American Honey achieves a higher standard of film making than commonly seen. And no, Shia LaBeouf does not ruin the movie.

Aesthetica Short Film Festival 2016: Day 2

Chloe Kent brings you the second day of Aesthetica, with a look at thrillers, dramas, and fashion film

Aesthetica Short Film Festival 2016: Day 1

Emily Taylor traipses through York to bring us coverage of the first day at the Aesthetica Short Film Festival

Review: I, Daniel Blake

I, Daniel Blake is a lesson in judgment and a call for compassion, says Fraser McHale

Review: Nocturnal Animals

Stylish, shocking, slick, Nocturnal Animals is the perfect cocktail of unease and brilliance, says Andrew Young

Review: The Girl on the Train

The Girl on the Train aims high, but ultimately falls flat, says Martha Wright

Review: Swiss Army Man

Arthouse cadaver comedy Swiss Army Man an unexpected delight, says Chloe Kent

Review: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children

Tim Burton's latest offering may not be his strongest, says Giulia De Vita, but it's still a charming watch

Review: My Scientology Movie

Chloe Kent examines Louis Theroux's feature length debut, and ponders the lighthearted nature of the piece

Review: War Dogs

Malou Van Rooij isn't impressed with this Miami Beach version of the Iraq War.

Review: Don't Breathe

Chloe Kent offers a rave review of Don't Breathe, the sophomore offering of Fede Alvarez

Suicide Squad Review: Take Two

Coco Clements is disappointed in the handling of Harley Quinn and the unsatisfying Suicide Squad.

Suicide Squad Review: Take One

Julia Callahan offers her take on Suicide Squad and the audience response. She's no fan of Amanda Waller.

Review: The Neon Demon

Chloe Kent finds The Neon Demon visually stunning, but prioritising style over substance

Review: The Conjuring 2

Lauren McNeilage finds that The Conjuring 2 manages to be one of those rare sequels to improve on its predecessor

Review: Me Before You

Mark Curran finds Me Without You a pleasant, but unexceptional, experience.

Review: The Lake

YSTV and York Student Cinema come together to show the thrilling tale of a group of York students who are thrown into a world of love, fear and paranoia after a mysterious encounter with the campus lake, says Liam Dooley

Review: X-Men Apocalypse

X-Men: Apocalypse joins Captain America: Civil War, Batman v. Superman and Deadpool as yet another disappointing superhero film for 2016, says Thomas Ron

Review: Everybody Wants Some!!

Richard Linklater knocks it out of the park with his first big project since Boyhood, says Chris Owen

Review: Captain America: Civil War

Captain America: Civil War takes the Marvel Cinematic Universe to an entirely different level, says Liam Dooley

Review: Eye in the Sky

The late Alan Rickman's last film is an intense spectacle that has you making decisions alongside its very realistic characters, say Thomas Ron

Review: Anomalisa

While Anomalisa steadfastly resists the beautiful, it is a film suffused with emotional deftness and a brutal underlying cynicism, says Louis Chilton
